subsc: Micro- and SME finance,Central government administration
trustfund:
TF022206-BNPP-POVERTY : POVERTY
            MONITORING AND ANALYSIS IN AFRICA,TF020970-REG. SECONDMENT STATISTICIAN (AFTHR),TF020350-DANISH CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND,TF038442-ZAMBIA:  SOCIAL RECOVERY II,TF036546-AFRICA, SOCIAL RECOVERY, WID (
            ZAMBIA, ETHIOPIA ),TF035275-ZAMBIA - SOCIAL RECOVERY
            PROJECT I & II,TF035006-ZAMBIA - EDUCATION STATISTICS,TF033316-ZAMBIA - EDUCATION REHAB.
            SOCIAL RECOVERY,TF032266-ZAMBIA - SOCIAL RECOVERY PROJECT,TF021123-SECOND SOCIAL RECOVERY PROJECT,TF020038-SECOND SOCIAL RECOVERY PROJECT-ZAMBIA,TF020036-SECOND SOCIAL RECOVERY PROJECT,TF023056-PHRD-SOCIAL RECOVERY II,TF023707-AFRICA POVERTY MONITORING &
            ANALYSIS PRG

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Social Recovery
            Project's outcome is rated satisfactory. The lessons
            learned from this project include: 1) Involvement of
            district level staff in the provision of technical support
            to communities has been beneficial. 2) Capacity of district
            level staff to plan, appraise, approve, and finance
            community initiative is variable, and their capacities
            should be strengthened in systematic way before they can
            take over these functions. 3) Continued training of district
            staff in participatory methodologies, technical aspects, and
            gender sensitivity will improve their ability to interact
            with communities. 4) Requiring community contributions
            instills a sense of ownership and responsibility for
            sub-projects, thus increasing sustainability. 5) A more
            coordinated approach to development in the districts could
            mitigate duplication of efforts by various partners who are
            supporting development activities in communities. 6)
            Maintenance issues are currently addressed up-front in the
            community initiative cycle. 7) The use of standard designs
            should be tempered with capacity of those implementing. 8)
            The requirement that 50% of the project committee be
            comprised of women has increased the decision-making role
            that women play in community affairs. 9) Providing formal
            linkages between those undertaking qualitative analysis and
            those carrying put quantitative analysis can provide
            government, NGOs, and donors with more robust information on
            which to formulate poverty policies.
